paper_title: NoTeeline: Supporting Real-Time, Personalized Notetaking with LLM-Enhanced Micronotes

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: Taking notes quickly while effectively capturing key information can be challenging, especially when watching videos that present simultaneous visual and auditory streams. Manually taken notes often miss crucial details due to the fast-paced nature of the content, while automatically generated notes fail to incorporate user preferences and discourage active engagement with the content. To address this, we propose an interactive system, NoTeeline, for supporting real-time, personalized notetaking. Given 'micronotes', NoTeeline automatically expands them into full-fledged notes using Large Language Model (LLM). The generated notes build on the content of micronotes by adding relevant details while maintaining consistency with the user's writing style. In a within-subjects study (n=12), we found that NoTeeline creates high-quality notes that capture the essence of their micronotes with 93.2% factual correctness and accurately align with their writing style (8.33% improvement). Using NoTeeline, participants could capture their desired notes with significantly reduced mental effort, writing 47.0% less text and completing their note in 43.9% less time compared to a manual notetaking baseline. Our results suggest that NoTeeline enables users to integrate LLM assistance in a familiar notetaking workflow while ensuring consistency with their preference.

1 INTRODUCTION
Effective notetaking is crucial for capturing and organizing in-
formation, allowing users to record essential details for later re-
view. Whether in academic, professional, or personal settings, notes
help individuals track important points, revisit information when
needed, and maintain focus on the task at hand without getting
overwhelmed by the flow of information. However, notetaking can
be very challenging in a fast-paced environment, such as when
watching information-dense videos or videos that are difficult to
pause. Users may struggle with the high mental demands, forcing
them to divide their attention between absorbing new content and
documenting it [30, 63, 64]. For example, when taking notes from
information-dense videos, people often pause the video frequently
in order to write notes, which disrupts the natural flow of content
engagement [9] and forces the user to dedicate mental and physical
effort to the mechanical act of notetaking. The inability to pause
(e.g. in some live-streamed content or content on platforms that
lack full media controls) adds even more pressure, often resulting in
incomplete notes that may be difficult to interpret later [19, 34, 47]
sections.content: "The more content you try to capture during lecture or meeting, the less youre thinking about whats being said. You burn through most of your attention parroting the source." - Ryder Carroll [10] With the emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs,) people have explored building automated notetaking tools, such as NoteGPT [54, 55, 58]. These tools typically work by automatically generating notes or summaries from the video transcript or live lecture recordings in one go. Thus, the generated notes lack personalization [6]. For example, the notes may be too general and not tailored to the users specific needs. user may only be interested in specific topics of the material, or they might prefer their notes to be written in particular style that reflects how they process information. Automated notes can feel impersonal and robotic [6]. Prior studies have observed that, in fast-paced notetaking situations, people often resort to shorthand techniques like micronotes[43]. For example, they may jot down short keypoints containing shortened words or informational notations in order to write things down more quickly (see Figure 1a). However, while micronotes help users keep up with the pace, they are often too brief or vague to be useful during the later review. As result, these micronotes are often abandoned and not revisited [37]. Thus, we observed gap between quickly capturing information and having detailed, meaningful notes that can be revisited with clarity. In this work, we leverage the practice of micro-notetaking and build an assistive tool around this practice, specifically for videos. Video content presents unique challenge for notetaking due to its temporal nature and often being information-dense, which leaves little time for users to capture important details. We introduce NoTeeline1, an interactive notetaking assistance tool that aims to automatically expand user micronotes into complete notes in realtime that also aligns with their personal writing style. We propose novel pipeline that leverages window of the video transcript as well as handful of examples of the users previous notes. Through within-subjects user study, we found that NoTeeline helps users effectively capture notes with minimal disruption (e.g., reduced video pauses), capturing more content using fewer words and shorter time compared to manual notetaking baseline. Participants rate the generated note expansions as high quality (average 6.0 on 7point Likert scale, higher is better), align with the participants micronote content (relatively high semantic similarity between micronotes and expanded notes measured with SBERT score [66]), are consistent with participants writing style (8.33% improvement in chi-squared Distance [36]), and the notes contain low hallucination (93.2% factual correctness score measured with HHEM score [80]). In summary, this work makes the following contributions. (1) We designed NoTeeline, an interactive notetaking tool built around the concept of micronotes. NoTeeline helps users write quick notes in fast-paced contexts and utilizes LLMs to expand micronotes into full-fledged notes. (2) We conducted within-subjects user study to evaluate the performance and utility of NoTeeline. Our quantitative and qualitative results show that with NoTeeline, users can take high-quality notes with higher efficiency and satisfaction, compared to manual notetaking baseline.

2 RELATED WORKS
2.1 Tools for Supporting Active Notetaking
Active notetaking has been long practiced as an efficient strategy
to store and retain information [4, 62]. Past research has intro-
duced several interactive notetaking tools to support live-notes
writing [26, 27, 45, 77, 79, 81], inking [9, 20, 92], information scaf-
folding [5, 74] and note organization [25, 49, 70, 73]. NoteLook
supports multimedia note taking in meetings in an integrated con-
ference room [13]. VideoSticker proposes a visual notetaking tool
for lecture videos utilizing object symbols to create multimodal,
non-linear notes [9]. AQuA introduces a question-answering inter-
face that helps users to watch software tutorial videos to get quick
information [85]. Livenote allows students to take lecture notes and
annotate lecture slides cooperatively [35]. NoteLink allows students
to link their hand-written notes with the relevant video so that they
can replay it easily [71]. Although these tools help users to organize
and link source materials faster, users still have to write the whole
note manually, often requiring additional laborious revisions and
manual effort, causing a significant cognitive barrier [64]. On the
contrary, NoTeeline focuses on automatically generating the text
of full notes from micronotes to shift effort from text notation to
capturing key ideas during active notetaking with usersâ€™ own note
points.

4 NEEDFINDING
4.1 Procedure
We conducted a needfinding study to understand the current chal-
lenges users encounter with their current notetaking process. Specif-
ically, we want to uncover underlying factors that make writing
the full note difficult. The results of this study informed the design
choices we made for NoTeeline. Each session was approximately
20-30 minutes long.
sections.content: Our participants reported using both manual notetaking tools as well as AI-assisted tools. The most common app used by participants was the built-in Macbook Notes app (ğ‘› = 9). Many participants use pen-and-paper notes (ğ‘› = 7) and later digitize them manually. In terms of AI-based tools, some participants used ChatGPT (ğ‘› = 4) for summarizing meetings and video lectures. Others used Notion AI, Figjam AI, and Gemini plugin in Google Docs for specific use cases.

sections.title:
4.2 Insights and Observations
Participants highlighted several challenges they face with their
current notetaking process. We summarize these findings into three
key themes through iterative rounds of coding guided by qualitative
data analysis [86]:
sections.content: C1. Users struggle to capture all desired information while taking notes from audio, video, and other real-time sources (ğ‘› = 7). Users mention resource constraintstime, attention, and mental loadin the practice of notetaking. P8 explains how their handwriting speed cannot match professors lecturing pace. P7 details the additional difficulties imposed by being non-native English speaker. P11 finds it challenging to take notes while listening to podcasts, especially during physical activities like running on treadmill. They describe the cumbersome process to jot down: have to slow down.. and then type it down in [a few words]... then again need to speed up the treadmill and continue. The user emphasizes how the ad hoc nature of this process complicates effective notetaking, making it difficult to capture details in real time. C2. Lack of agency in AI-assisted notetaking tools (ğ‘› = 6). Users expressed the desire to maintain agency over AI-assisted notetaking tools. This is important given concerns about LLM hallucinating non-existent content [32]. P1 says would, at the end of the day, want some kind of source of truth... based on what the notes are going to be. They reported to prefer using automated note features as compliment to whatever that [theyre] using while always going to take [their] notes no matter how, because of the lack of trust in it. P2 further explains her thought - hope its tool for me... to help me get better understanding of the video, not tool for me to tell me what should know because still want myself to have the control of what the tool is doing. C3. Complex features and workflow of current tools. (ğ‘› = 7). Participants highlighted that the complex features and fragmented workflow of current notetaking tools often hinder usability. One common challenge involved managing two separate applicationsone for watching videos and another for taking noteswhich made the Conference17, July 2017, Washington, DC, USA Faria Huq, Abdus Samee, David Chuan-en Lin, Xiaodi Alice Tang, and Jeffrey P. Bigham process cumbersome. They expressed desire for having notetaking features within the video application, as this would facilitate more seamless interaction, especially if the notes are linked to specific video segments to aid in later review. Furthermore, participants reported that the overwhelming nature of feature-rich tools like Notion discouraged full utilization. As P5 described, dont end up using the extent of features that Notion has to offer... its so overwhelming .. so [I prefer] simple interface but with the ability that as you go forward, you can start to explore more. In other words, the features are not well-situated or contextualized within the workflow, and presenting them all at once can overwhelm users, preventing them from fully utilizing the benefits.

sections.title:
4.3 Design Goals
Based on our needfinding study, iterative prototyping, and evalua-
tion process, we propose three design goals for NoTeeline.
sections.content: D1. Micronotetaking as the way to take notes from videos to assist rapid writing. The tool should support the quick creation of micronotes and be able to automatically expand it into full note so that users do not need to write down all the details (C1). Even if the micronote includes grammatical errors or is extremely short, the system should be able to comprehend it. While transforming micronotes, it should be aware of the context, i.e., the topic being discussed in the video. The system should also support iterative editing of micronotes. D2. Maintain consistency with users writing style and preferences to ensure user agency. The system should take into account the specific writing styles of the user and remain consistent with their personal style. At the same time, the final note should exclude information users are not interested in and should not include any hallucinated information (C2). D3. Each component is linked to specific stage of the notetaking process to enhance ease of use. The system should link each component to specific stage in the notetaking processcreation, editing, and revision. It should allow users to engage selectively with these features based on the current stage, providing ease of use throughout the notetaking process (C3)[52, 61].

sections.title:
5.1.2 Notetaking Layout. . To better situate the interface around
an effective workflow, we took inspiration from the Cornell method
to construct the layout [60, 63, 67]. We have three main regions
sections.content: 1) Notes: the region for writing and organizing notes; 2) Cues: auto-generated questions to review the note; and 3) Summary: main takeaway of the note. We also incorporated the video viewport on the top of the layout so that users can take notes while watching the video without needing to move between different desktop tabs. NoTeeline progressively discloses the features as per users current need for note writing, editing, or analyzing (D3). Figure 2 illustrates the notetaking layout and its different components.

sections.title:
5.1.3 Note Synthesis Operations. We describe individual syn-
thesis operations NoTeeline supports and their mechanism.
sections.content: Micronote Expansion. To construct the full note, we have an atomic expansion operation. For expansion, we utilize these pieces of information in the prompt: micronote, video transcript where the micronote was written, and reference examples from onboarding. The transcript helps to infer abbreviated symbols and fix potential typographical errors (D1) [78]. Reference examples help to understand users writing style (D2). Figure 3 shows an example of micronote expansion. Note Organization by Theme. To rearrange the note points by emerging themes, we have an atomic order by theme operation. To order by theme, we pass the generated notes to the LLM and instruct it to return the output in structured, parseable format by using the few-shot prompting technique [33, 56]. We refer users to view the corresponding prompt Figure 14 in the Appendix to learn more about the structure we chose to use. Figure 4 shows an example of how the note organization operation works. Note Modification. To edit individual micronotes or the expanded output from LLM and/or the automatically generated theme name (D3), users can click on the button next to each point. Note Rearrangement. To enable users rearrange their notes (D3), we have drag and drop operation. Users can drag individual note points and reposition them under different theme using this operation. Users can also revert the note to its original serial by order by time operation. Cue Question Generation. To enable users review their notes, we have Cue Question Generation operation, which generates 5 questions on-the-fly. If users want new questions, they have the option to initiate Regeneration operation, which generates five new questions. The cue column is hidden by default to provide more space for writing to the users (D3). Cue question is generated in similar structured fashion to order by theme operation. Please view the corresponding prompt (Figure 15) in the Appendix for details. Summary Generation. To generate personalized summary, we have Summarize operation. The generated summary needs to reflect the users note as well as the video context (D2). Hence, we passed the full video transcript and expanded the note to LLM for the summary.

6 PROTOTYPE IMPLEMENTATION
NoTeeline is implemented using React.js and is hosted as a web app.
All LLM-based operations and text manipulation are performed
using the OpenAI model, GPT-4-Turbo with hyperparameters set
to temperature = 0.5, seed = 1. We chose GPT-4 over other LLMs
due to its high-quality output and support for a longer size context
window, especially suitable for longer videos [56]. We store all the
data locally using Chrome localstorage.

sections.title:
7 USER EVALUATION
With our user evaluation, we aimed to explore the following re-
search questions:
sections.content: RQ1. Can NoTeeline help users take notes efficiently with reduced disruption? RQ2. Can NoTeeline generate note expansions that align with the users micronote and personal writing style? Participants. We invited 12 participants from our needfinding interviews to participate in user study. Participants used both NoTeeline and baseline to capture notes and evaluate their performance. They were divided into four subgroups to counterbalance and mitigate any ordering bias. Table 3 shows the distribution of participants across these subgroups. User Study Procedure. We first gave an overview of the study procedures to the participants. Participants were given the NoTeeline web app link to browse from their laptops. They began with the onboarding session where we collected their personalized writing examples (B.1). After onboarding, participants were given two videos (B.2) to watch and take notes under the two study conditions. To prevent potential fatigue, participants were given 5-minute break in between each video. After each video notetaking session, users were asked to complete questionnaire [7, 24, 68]. Finally, we asked participants to try out NoTeeline with video of their choice. Each session was one hour long. Baseline. To compare NoTeeline with baseline, i.e., basic notes app, we used simplified view of our interface by hiding all advanced features (i.e., the synthesis functions described in 5.1.3). This setting mimics the standalone Macbook Notes app, which most of the participants reported using. We also want to compare the utility between the personalized summary in NoTeeline and the automatically generated summary in existing tools. Hence, we kept the summary feature in the baseline which is similar to NoteGPT [54], i.e., summary that is not conditioned on user notes, rather just summarizes the video transcript.

sections.title: Notetaking Experience
sections.content: While one might argue that spending more time to write individual notes is better way to get deeper engagement with the materials, and NoTeeline might seem to deviate users from writing effective notes, we argue that NoTeeline does not detract, but rather enhances the engagement in more meaningful ways. First, users are still responsible for initiating which parts of the material to take notes for and what information they want to capture, with NoTeeline simply helping to transform their input into fuller structured notes more suitable for later review. In contrast to existing fully automated tools, users are actively involved in notetaking. Second, NoTeeline reduces the disruption in watching videos caused when taking full notes (e.g., constantly having to pause the video) and freeing them from the mechanical task of writing. Thus, It helps maintain the uninterrupted flow of information. Third, NoTeeline also allows deeper involvement in note analysis and revision stages. After the users have finished taking the notes, they can always come back to it and edit, reorganize, and revise based on their needs. Our system provides features to review notes by the cue question, to manually edit the automatically expanded notes, to jump to the location where the note was taken, and to organize the notes in their desired structure and themes. These features were inspired by the Cornell notetaking system with their long history of improving long-term knowledge retention [18, 38, 88]. All these factors altogether enable users to deeply engage with content in NoTeeline.

sections.title: Notetaking Tools
sections.content: Based on our findings from the design and evaluation of NoTeeline, we highlight three insights to inform the future design of human-AI collaborative notetaking systems. First, our findings reveal that the greatest benefit of NoTeeline is the affordance of the micro note and its expansion. Being able to continue writing notes within their usual workflow while enjoying LLM assistance sparks interest. The ability to toggle back and forth between the original and modified notes enhances their overall experience by providing control over the content, critical factor in fostering user trust [31]. Future tools should support iterative processing, including automatic cleaning of grammatical errors, and offer both LLM-assisted and manual options for editing and organizing notes. Second, collaborative notetaking systems should provide granular user control. In our needfinding study, users mention concerns about LLM hallucination and lack of control in AI-assisted tools (4.2). Prior Research shows that trust in human-machine teaming can be positively impacted through transparency [1]. By giving users the ability to control precise moments to take notes and writing styles to maintain instead of relegating the generation task entirely to software NoTeeline can increase transparency in the notetaking process. Finally, an AI-assisted system should leverage implicit guidance [29] from users to regulate its generation quality. In NoTeeline, users would take micronotes as usual while implicitly guiding the system about what to focus on in the generated note. Such support for implicit guidance does not require additional effort from the user such as writing custom prompts for their individual requests every time.

While our study demonstrates that NoTeeline significantly reduces cognitive load and improves notetaking efficiency by minimizing writing effort and time, we did not measure the long-term effect of NoTeeline on information retention. The primary goal of this work was to evaluate the systems ability to facilitate efficient note-taking, not to assess how the generated notes impact user learning outcomes. This follows standard practice in prior research, as seen in works like Rambler[44] and VideoSticker[9]. Nonetheless, for future work, we could investigate how NoTeeline can influence information retention through longitudinal study.

11 CONCLUSION
Active notetaking from videos remains challenging. While existing
tools can automatically generate notes, they do not necessarily
capture the details and stylistic nuances users care about. Our
needfinding study reveals that users often do not prefer automati-
cally generated notes due to concerns about accuracy and lack of
customization. On the other hand, NoTeeline leverages rich contex-
tual information to generate more accurate and more personalized
notes. Our user study reveals that NoTeeline helps write notes
faster with 93.2% correctness and achieves closer stylistic charac-
teristics to usersâ€™ handwritten notes. We demonstrate the utility of
NoTeeline in a variety of usage scenarios users reported and pro-
vide design implications for future works in AI-assisted notetaking
systems.
sections.content: SOCIETAL IMPACT By helping users take notes faster, NoTeeline has the potential to make notetaking more accessible for individuals who might otherwise struggle with factors such as language fluency (e.g., as demonstrated by P7s comments about difficulties of being nonnative English speaker) and physical disabilities. While there exist arguments about whether over-reliance on AI-generated content may lead to passive engagement or diminish personal organizational skills, we show how our tool exists to amplify, not override, user engagement in the generation process. We also expect this to decrease the risk of AI biases that might otherwise occur in fully autogenerated notes without any sort of user engagement. The videos met the following criteria: 1) not too long (< 5 minutes); 2) information heavy where users are exposed to scientific concepts ( so that they feel the need to take note); 3) interesting to wide range of audience. Based on these criteria, we selected two TED-Ed videos entitled How memories form and how we lose them (url1) and Is it possible to lose weight fast? (url2).
